hostNotes.text: Welcome. I am X and today we will explore equanimity and excpectations  for around 20 minutes. We’ll be doing an audio exercise, followed by time for reflection and finally sharing with each other – if we're up for it.

Let’s start with a mini check-in. How are you feeling right now? Please answer in two-three words. X, would you like to start?  

> Let everyone in the session, including yourself, check in one by one. 

Thank you all for checking in. Let’s get started.

content.heading: Welcome
content.text: This session will explore equanimity and excpectations.

hostNotes.text:
Find a comfortable position. I will start the audio exercise and we'll meet back here afterwards. 

> Tap play to start the audio exercise

content.heading: Reflection
content.text: You can take notes on a piece of paper or just mental notes in your head. And there is no right or wrong here, our answers are our own.

What do you notice about your list of “helpful expectations”? 

Do they seem doable? 

Do you see any themes or generalities?

What do you notice about your list of “unhelpful expectations”?
content.heading: Reflection

content.text:
What do the items on this list have in common, if anything? 

What impact might these “unhelpful expectations” be having on you?

What do you notice about feelings or sensations that arise in you as you think carefully about these expectations you’re holding for yourself today?
content.heading: Reflection

hostNotes.text:
Now we’ll take 1 minutes to reflect on our own. 

How was that experience for you? 

What do you notice about your list of “helpful expectations”? 

Do they seem doable? 

Do you see any themes or generalities?

What do you notice about your list of “unhelpful expectations”? 

What do the items on this list have in common, if anything? 

What impact might these “unhelpful expectations” be having on you?
What do you notice about feelings or sensations that arise in you as you think carefully about these expectations you’re holding for yourself today?

You can take notes on a piece of paper or just mental notes in your head. And there is no right or wrong here, our answers are our own. 1 minute starting now. 

> Press play to start the timer. 

That’s 1 minute and it’s time to move on.

Now we are getting into the sharing part. We have three rules for sharing:

1. **What is said in here, stays in here.**
2. **All you need to do is listen.** There is no fixing, helping or advice-giving needed. We are just showing up and exploring what ourselves and others are going through.

3. **Everything on the inside is okay.** Anger, love, hatred, sadness. Whatever shows up. No wrongs, no rights. It is what it is.

There will be a timer set for 2 minutes as an indicator. If you don’t want to share you can always say ‘pass’.

Who would like to start?

> Let everyone (or as many as you got time for) share one by one. Press play to start the timer. Re-start for each new sharing.

Thank you so much everyone.

content.heading: What do you notice about your list of “helpful expectations”? Do they seem doable? Do you see any themes or generalities?
What do you notice about your list of “unhelpful expectations”?
What do you notice about feelings or sensations that arise?

hostNotes.text: Well done. Today, we’ve explored equanimity and expectations. Equanimity offers us the opportunity to accept whatever comes in life with calmness and stability.
Managing our expectation can form a crucial part of this process by providing us with realistic perceptions and goal aiding our ability remain grounded in what is present for us.

If we're up for it, we can continue with a mission: Practice our awareness of our expectations by noticing if expectations arise over the coming two days and analysing if they are helpful or unhelpful.

Plan the steps you will take by considering if you have any situations related to expectations arising in the coming days. Before we leave this space, let’s do a mini check-out: How are you feeling right now? Has anything shifted? Please answer in two to three words.

Who would like to start? 

> Let everyone in the session check out one by one. 

Thank you all for checking out and for joining this session today. 

> Finish session to send everyone off to the exit experience.

content.text: Well done. Today, we’ve explored equanimity and expectations. Equanimity offers us the opportunity to accept whatever comes in life with calmness and stability.
content.heading: Compassion

content.text: Managing our expectation can form a crucial part of this process by providing us with realistic perceptions and goal aiding our ability remain grounded in what is present for us.
content.heading: Compassion

content.text:
If we're up for it, we can continue with a mission: Practice our awareness of our expectations by noticing if expectations arise over the coming two days and analysing if they are helpful or unhelpful.

Plan the steps you will take by considering if you have any situations related to expectations arising in the coming days.
content.heading: Compassion

en.name: Expectations

hostNotes.text: > Press play to start the exercise

en.description: We can learn to accept that not everything is within their control. Sometimes, even with the best efforts, we may not achieve what they had hoped for.. When we exercise self-compassion we can set expectations for ourselves out of a desire to be healthy and flourishing rather than from a place of self-criticism.
